info.game_comments:
Chuck Forrest game 4.
Chuck sets a new total cash winnings record of $60,000.

(1, 1).clue: Jim Davis named this cat after his grandfather, not the 20th president

(2, 1).clue: Used as early as 230 B.C., the 1st successful electric one was developed by the Otis Bros. in 1889

(3, 1).clue: Movie question posed by Barbra Streisand & Bugs Bunny

(4, 1).clue: The only mammal capable of sustained flight

(5, 1).clue: Herbs anise & fennel resemble the flavor of this common black candy

(1, 2).clue: John Steinbeck wrote the preface of a book about this Al Capp character

(2, 2).clue: Begun by Appius Claudius as a public work in 312 B.C., it's one of the roads that lead to Rome

(3, 2).clue: Dustin Hoffman & Alec Guinness were considered for this role that won an Oscar for Ben Kingsley

(4, 2).clue: Of a rat, a raven, & a spineless jellyfish the one which can be taught to count

(5, 2).clue: From the Romanian word for "to preserve", it's served hot with mustard on rye

(1, 3).clue: Standard comment of Little Orphan Annie's dog Sandy

(2, 3).clue: Type of well named for the French region of Artois where 1 was 1st drilled in 1126

(3, 3).clue: Some of the character names rejected for this classic were "Gaspy", "Daffy", & "Snoopy"
(3, 3).correct response: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs

(4, 3).clue: A luna moth's are feathered, a june bug's leaflike, & a cockroach's are feelers

(5, 3).clue: When it was 1st introduced into England from France, it was called "butterine"

(6, 3).clue: Soft white Italian cheese often used as pizza topping

(2, 4).clue: A 1984 survey found an additional 2,500 miles to this barrier, now totaling 6,200 miles long

(3, 4).clue: The make of car that starts up immediately after 200 years in Woody Allen's "Sleeper"

(4, 4).clue: Since 1955 ultrasonic vibrations have repelled these crusty creatures from ship hulls

(5, 4).clue: Named for an English dr. who recommended meat as cure-all, it's a hamburger without a bun

(6, 4).clue: A gathering at which Pete Seeger & Joan Baez, or an owl & a goat might sing

(2, 5).clue: This 15th century artist built fortresses, bridges, harbors, & locks

(4, 5).clue: Often called the panther, its name was originally given to the cat now known as the cheetah

(5, 5).clue: Not a fabric but a cake that's a cross between an angel & a sponge

(1, 1).clue: This author of "The Jungle Book" lived in Vermont for 4 years

(2, 1).clue: This British/Australian group's name was taken from oldest brother Barry's initials

(3, 1).clue: Dorothy Parker said, "Men seldom make passes at girls who" do this

(4, 1).clue: Presidents Hayes, Garfield, & Benjamin Harrison were all generals in this war

(5, 1).clue: In 1965, Pope Paul VI formally exonerated this group of blame for the death of Jesus

(6, 1).clue: Largest Chinese community outside Asia lives in this city's Chinatown

(3, 2).clue: Emerson said, "If a man makes a better" one of these, "the world will beat a path to his door"

(4, 2).clue: General who told Congress in 1951, "There is no substitute for victory"

(5, 2).clue: It's what the P.T.L. in TV's "P.T.L. Club" stands for
(5, 2).correct response: Praise the Lord (or People that Love)

(6, 2).clue: Of a North, East, South & West Side, the 1 Chicago doesn't have

(1, 3).clue: James Hilton's schoolmaster father was the model for this novel's title character

(2, 3).clue: In '67, this "Lady of Soul" got due "Respect"

(3, 3).clue: "The doctor can bury his mistakes, but we can only advise clients to plant vines", said this architect

(4, 3).clue: Generals Lee, Grant, Sherman, Pershing, & Patton have all had a type of these named for them

(6, 3).clue: The Village Stompers stomped around this part of Greenwich Village:

(1, 4).clue: The hero's clubfoot in "Of Human Bondage" represented this author's stammer

(3, 4).clue: Completes the quote "Go west, young man"
(3, 4).correct response: and grow up with the country

(4, 4).clue: "Old Fuss & Feathers", general Winfield Scott, captured this foreign capital in 1847

(5, 4).clue: North American Protestant group featured in the movie "Witness"

(6, 4).clue: Founded in 1683, Germantown is now an historic part of this city

(1, 5).clue: Ironically Catherine, wife of this poet, painter, & printer, was illiterate

(3, 5).clue: "Reading is to the mind as" this is "to the body"

(4, 5).clue: With under 200 men, this Revolutionary War general captured 3 British forts in Ill. & Ind.

(5, 5).clue: Prayer taken from salutation of Gabriel, it's now said as commonly as the Lord's Prayer

(0, 0).clue: Last Communist party chief of the U.S.S.R. to leave office without dying
